thread.title: A closer look: Dion Lewis TD catch against the Cowboys | The Blitz | with Jeff Howe & Karen Guregian
thread.title_full: A closer look: Dion Lewis TD catch against the Cowboys | The Blitz | with Jeff Howe & Karen Guregian | Boston Herald

author: Adam Kurkjian
title: A closer look: Dion Lewis TD catch against the Cowboys | The Blitz | with Jeff Howe & Karen Guregian
text:
One last look back on a play that helped the Patriots put away the Cowboys on Sunday, when Dion Lewis made an incredible individual effort on a touchdown in the third quarter to give the Patriots a 20-3 lead in the eventual 30-6 victory. It was a well-designed play but, in the end, relied on the quickness, cutting ability and power of Lewis to get in the end zone.
Let's take a closer look at the Dion Lewis catch-and-run for a 10-yard score in the third quarter that pushed the Pats ahead, 20-3.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 First note the 3-2-6 defensive alignment Belichick talked about after the game. The Cowboys run it here. pic.twitter.com/JEblIauDOf
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Note Gronkowski's position for now and how he will later help force the numbers in the Pats' favor on the other side pic.twitter.com/Kp87TY86Hq
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Edelman motions, drawing his man to the other side along with the eyes of the safeties, LBs, who have to respect it. pic.twitter.com/mfWU4nvdyF
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 A lot happens once the ball is snapped. What essentially transpires is a screen play with no linemen keying it off. pic.twitter.com/r8C5vh7Z8s
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Notice first how every lineman goes one way. The only "blocking" for Lewis is a "pick" set by Amendola. Since Lewis is behind the LOS...
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 a player can block downfield if Lewis is still behind the LOS. Amendola does not.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 He does draw in his man, however, essentially sending two players off in the wrong direction.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Notice also Gronkowski at the top of the screen. He is double-covered and the safety had to respect both Edelman and Gronk there, so...
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 he's leaning the wrong way, too. There's only 1 player out of 10 who isn't either on the wrong side of the field or caught looking that way
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 This only lasts about a second, though, as this is what awaits Lewis once he catches the ball with one hand due to a pic.twitter.com/Y0MM720lg1
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Brady throw that forced him to turn around. Note how much room there is on the sidelines. That's where most backs go in this situation.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Brady throw that forced him to turn around. Note how much room there is on the sidelines. That's where most backs go in this situation.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 That's also where the closest defender expects Lewis to go, but as you can see, Lewis has already planted his right foot, setting up a cut
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 That's also where the closest defender expects Lewis to go, but as you can see, Lewis has already planted his right foot, setting up a cut
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 to the inside. This is where it gets ridiculous.
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 After that cut, this is where Lewis is. He uses his height to his advantage to duck out of the next tackle attempt. pic.twitter.com/Qauw1LkEAV
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 Now, Lewis has to fight through for three more yards, and most of his work is done. pic.twitter.com/0C9WlHkbaQ
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 He takes the hit at the 2-yard line and uses the force of it to pinball forward into the end zone. pic.twitter.com/QvxAN3UKYO
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015 This is all power, basically. There aren't many players who can do this type of thing. pic.twitter.com/tXV1vW5C9k
— Adam Kurkjian (@AdamKurkjian) October 12, 2015
